{{Infobox Airline |airline = Aero Benin |logo = Aero Benin logo.gif |logo_size = |fleet_size = |destinations = Bamako, Cotonou, Ouagadoudou, Pointe Noire, Brazzaville |IATA = EM |ICAO = AEB |callsign = AEROBEN |parent = |company_slogan = |founded = 2002<ref>http://aviation-safety.net/database/operator/airline.php?var=8388</ref> |ceased = ? |headquarters = Bamako<ref>http://lemali.org/en/mali-pages-jaunes/Offices%20de%20Tourisme/aero-benin</ref> |key_people = |hubs = [[Brazzaville]] (Congo) - Maya-Maya airport<ref>http://www.ourairports.com/airlines/EM/</ref> |secondary_hubs = Cotonou, Ouagadoudou |focus_cities = |frequent_flyer = |lounge = |alliance = |website = Does not have a website }}
'''Aero Benin''' was an [[airline]], based in [[Benin]] but registered in Germany, which carried out land and sea freight as well as passenger services.<ref>http://flights.idealo.co.uk/airline/Aero-Benin-EM/{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> As of 8 April 2009 it is banned within the European Union<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/operator/airline.php?var=8388|title=Aviation Safety Network > ASN Aviation Safety Database > Operator index > Benin > Aero Benin|last=Ranter|first=Harro|website=aviation-safety.net|access-date=2017-09-13}}</ref> and as of July, 2012, it is inactive.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ch-aviation.ch/portal/airline.php?cha=EM|title=Aéro Bénin on ch-aviation|website=ch-aviation|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-13}}</ref>
==Fleet== Aero Benin appear not to have had a fleet of their own,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.planespotters.net/Airline/Aero-Benin|title=Aero Benin Fleet Details and History|website=www.planespotters.net|language=en|access-date=2017-09-13}}</ref> rather they code-shared with [[Boeing 727]] aircraft (and [[Boeing 737]] aircraft for flights between N'Djamena and Cotonou)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ourairports.com/airlines/EM/|title=Aero Benin (EM) @ OurAirports|website=www.ourairports.com|access-date=2017-09-13}}</ref>
==Destinations==
Aero Benin flew the following routes:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.interair.co.za/timetable.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151220110946/http://www.interair.co.za/timetable.asp |archivedate=2015-12-20 }}</ref><ref>http://www.ourairports.com/airlines/EM/</ref>

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=June 2009}} {{Infobox Coat of arms |name = Coat of arms of Kiev |image = COA of Kyiv Kurovskyi.svg |image_width = 150 |lesser = |lesser_width = |lesser_caption = |armiger = [[Kiev]] |year_adopted = 18 April 1995 |crest = |torse = |shield = [[Azure (heraldry)|Azure]] |supporters = |compartment = |motto = |orders = |other_elements = |earlier_versions = |use = }}
The '''coat of arms of [[Kiev]]''' features the [[Archangel Michael]], wielding a flaming [[sword]] and a shield on an [[azure (heraldry)|azure]] field.
==History== The coat of arms traces its history back to the medieval principality of [[Kievan Rus']], where the Archangel Michael was depicted on the seals used by the Kievan [[grand prince]]s. Initially the coat of arms of Kiev featured [[Saint George]] fighting a dragon on an azure field, and this today remains the coat of arms of the [[Kiev Oblast]]. In the 16th century, a coat consisting of the Archangel Michael clad in white robes, holding a sword and a [[shield]] on a red field was adopted for the [[Kiev Voivodeship]]. <!--picture needed-->
In 1487, along with [[Magdeburg rights]], the city of [[Kiev]] received a coat of arms consisting of a hand holding a [[crossbow]].
In 1782, a new coat of arms was approved by the order of [[Catherine II of Russia]]. In the order the coat of arms <!---of the region---> is described as "Archangel Michael in a short tunic on an azure field". Later on it was decorated with an imperial crown and other ornaments. No original image of the arms has been recovered to date. Some modern drawings of the arms exist, based on the description in Catherine's order.
In 1918, during the short time of Ukrainian independence, a coat of arms was adopted which contained, in addition to the Archangel Michael and the crossbow, a [[trident]] from the [[Coat of arms of Ukraine]], emphasizing the city's role as the nation's capital.
In 1957, a coat of arms was introduced with [[chestnut]] leaves and a bow on the red-azure field, containing the word КИЇВ (''KYIV''; Ukrainian for 'KIEV'), and such Soviet symbols as the [[hammer and sickle]] and the [[Hero City]] medal. Since 1973 the [[Aesculus hippocastanum|horse-chestnut]] leave became one of the symbols of the city.
In May 1995, the [[Kiev City Council]] restored the city's original coat of arms depicting the Archangel Michael.
==Gallery== <center> <gallery> Image:COA of Kiev 1480.png|Kiev Coat of Arms (1480). Image:Kyiv. Carsly Tytulyarnyk.png|Kiev land Coat of Arms (1672). Image:Kiev magistrat 1698.svg|Kiev city magistrate Coat of Arms (1698, on the seal). image:Герб Киева 1782 (Винклер) crop.png|Kiev Coat of Arms (1782; restored based on historical description). image:Киевская губерния изд Сукачова.png|[[Kiev Governorate]] Coat of Arms (1856). image:Kiev CoA Soviet.png|Kiev Coat of Arms (1969). </gallery> </center>
==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kiev}} [[Category:History of Kiev|Coat of arms]] [[Category:Ukrainian coats of arms]] [[Category:Coats of arms of cities in Ukraine]] [[Category:Coats of arms with angels|Kiev]] [[Category:Coats of arms with swords|Kiev]] [[Category:Coats of arms with crosses|Kiev]]

revision.text:
The '''Committee I''', or the '''Permanent Oversight Committee on the Intelligence and Security Services''' ({{lang-nl|Vast Comité van Toezicht op de inlichtingen- en veiligheidsdiensten}}, {{lang-fr|Comité permanent de contrôle des services de renseignements et de sécurité}}), exercises external oversight over the [[Belgian State Security Service]] and the [[Belgian General Information and Security Service|General Intelligence and Security Service]]. It is responsible to the [[Belgian Senate]], the [[upper house]] of the [[Belgian Federal Parliament]], which appoints and dismisses its members.
It consists of three members, including a Chairperson, who are appointed for a term of five years by the [[Belgian Senate]]. This term may be renewed only once. Its members are chosen from among magistrates, senior police officials or persons with significant administrative or scientific experience, however, the Chairperson must be a magistrate. The Chairperson of the Committee I is currently Guy Rapaille, Solicitor General at the Liège Court of Appeal, He was appointed by the Senate on 30 March 2006 and took the oath of office on 4 July 2006. The other two are Pieter-Alexander De Brock & Gerald Vande Walle both civil servants
==External links== *[http://www.comiteri.be/ Website of the Committee I]
[[Category:Government of Belgium]] [[Category:Belgian Federal Parliament]] [[Category:Legislative intelligence oversight]]
{{Belgium-stub}}

{{Infobox Union| |name= Pardia |country= [[Finland]] |affiliation= [[Finnish Confederation of Salaried Employees|STTK]] |members= 60,000 |full_name= Confederation of State Employees' Unions |native_name=Palkansaajajärjestö Pardia
Löntagarorganisationen Pardia |image= [[Image:PARDIA logo.png|175px]] |founded= |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Helsinki]], Finland |people= |website= [http://www.pardia.fi www.pardia.fi] |footnotes= }} The '''Confederation of State Employees' Unions''' (Pardia, {{lang-fi|Palkansaajajärjestö Pardia}}, {{lang-sv|Löntagarorganisationen Pardia}}) is a [[trade union]] in [[Finland]]. The majority of Pardia's 60,000 members work in governmental offices and institutions while others are employed by public utility companies and enterprises. Approximately 50 percent of all Finnish state employees are members of Pardia. Pardia is affiliated with the [[Finnish Confederation of Salaried Employees]]. ==References== *{{cite book | year = 2005 | title = Trade Unions of the World | editor = [[International Centre for Trade Union Rights|ICTUR]] et al., | edition = 6th | publisher = John Harper Publishing | location = London, UK | isbn = 0-9543811-5-7 }} ==External links== *http://www.pardia.fi/in_english/ {{Portal|Organized labour}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Confederation of State Employees' Unions - Pardia}} [[Category:Finnish Confederation of Salaried Employees]] [[Category:Trade unions in Finland]] {{Europe-trade-union-stub}} {{Finland-stub}}

(2018) | Next single = | Misc = }} "'''Cuba Libre'''" is a song recorded by Swedish rapper [[Moncho]]. The song was released as a digital download on 26 February 2018 and peaked at number 31 on the [[Sverigetopplistan|Swedish Singles Chart]]. It is taking part in [[Melodifestivalen 2018]], and qualified to andra chansen from the third semi-final on 17 February 2018. It was written by Moncho along with [[Jimmy Jansson]], David Strääf, Markus Videsäter, and [[Axel Schylström]].{{cite web|url=https://eurovoix.com/2018/02/17/sweden-martin-almgren/|title=Sweden: Martin Almgren and Jessica Andersson Advance To The Melodifestivalen 2018 Final|date=17 February 2018|publisher=Eurovoix|last=McCraig|first=Ewan}} ==Track listing== {{Track listing | headline = Digital download{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/sv/album/cuba-libre/1347908175?i=1347908183|title=Cuba Libre – Single|publisher=iTunes|accessdate=24 February 2018}} | title1 = Cuba Libre | length1 = 2:47 | title2 = Cuba Libre | length2 = 2:42 | note2 = Instrumental }} ==Charts== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! {{Orphan|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Deneb Karentz |image = |caption = |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |other_names = |nationality =[[Armenian-American]] |fields = [[Marine biology]]
[[Ozone depletion]] |workplaces =Professor, [[University of San Francisco]] |alma_mater = BS [[University of Rhode Island]]
MS [[Oregon State University]]
PhD [[University of Rhode Island]] |known_for = |website = [https://www.usfca.edu/faculty/deneb-karentz Deneb Karentz at University of San Francisco] |occupation = }} '''Deneb Karentz''' is full-time faculty, professor, and chair of the Biology Department at [[University of San Francisco]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.usfca.edu/faculty/deneb-karentz|title=Deneb Karentz|last=|date=2015-07-06|website=University of San Francisco|access-date=2016-05-17}} Her research focuses the [[ultraviolet]] [[photobiology]] of marine organisms and understanding their strategies for protection from UV exposure, particularly in relation to the ecological implications of [[Antarctic]] ozone depletion. == Early Life and education == Karentz grew up in Millis, MA, the daughter of Rose and Varoujan Karentz, and turned to athletics in high school as a two-sport captain to complement a proud academic standing. Karentz earned her BS at the [[University of Rhode Island]] in 1973, MS at [[Oregon State University]] in 1976 and PhD at the University of Rhode Island in 1982.{{Cite web|url=http://advance.uri.edu/quadangles/sept2007/story10.htm|title=Class Acts Profiles|website=advance.uri.edu|access-date=2016-05-17}} Her graduate research focused on the physiology and ecology of marine [[phytoplankton]]. She has lived in San Francisco, California since 1983. She held an NIH National Service Award Fellowship for post-doctoral research at the Laboratory of Radiobiology and Environmental Health, University of California San Francisco from 1983-1986. She worked in the lab of [http://cancer.ucsf.edu/people/profiles/cleaver_james.3557 James E. Cleaver], conducting research on the molecular genetics of an inherited human disease, xeroderma pigmentosum (XP). Patients afflicted with XP are extremely sensitive to sunlight and are unable to repair UV-induced damage to DNA. Karentz remained at UCSF as a research biologist until hired as a professor of Biology and Environmental Science at the University of San Francisco in 1992. == Career and impact == Karentz became involved in Antarctic research in 1986 as a volunteer on a field team studying the photophysiology of springtime phytoplankton in McMurdo Sound. Karentz's research focuses on the ultraviolet [[photobiology]] of marine organisms: identifying strategies for protection from UV exposure and understanding mechanisms for repair of UV–induced damage. Her work has focused on investigating the ecological implications of Antarctic [[ozone depletion]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1989/11/06/will-ozone-depletion-disrupt-antarcticas-ecosystem/f56ad9ea-93b3-488b-a041-08efa7ea7f98/|title=Will Ozone Depletion Disrupt Antarctica's Ecosystem?|last=Booth|first=William|date=6 November 1989|work=The Washington Post|access-date=19 May 2016|via=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1990/07/31/ozone-hole-may-harm-marine-life/999972b2-4c8b-41d7-af11-8bf7aedde626/|title=Ozone Hole May Harm Marine Life|last=Booth|first=William|date=31 July 1990|work=The Washington Post|access-date=19 May 2016|via=}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1993/04/15/in-the-debate-about-ozone-no-depletion-in-rhetoric/124a6433-3c77-4cc7-9d7f-28571876bcf3/|title=In the Debate About Ozone, No Depletion in Rhetoric|last=|first=|date=15 April 1993|work=The Washington Post|access-date=19 May 2016|via=}} Over the past 30 years, she has made the trip to Antarctica over 20 times.{{Cite web|url=http://armenianweekly.com/2015/10/12/living-with-the-penguins-in-antarctica/|title=Living with the Penguins in Antarctica|last=Hairenik|date=2015-10-12|website=Armenian Weekly|access-date=2016-05-17}} Most of her research has focused on the effects of ozone depletion on marine [[plankton]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/01/07/science/broad-effort-under-way-to-track-ozone-hole-s-effects.html?pagewanted=all|title=Broad Effort Under Way to Track Ozone Hole's Effects|last=Browne|first=Malcolm W.|date=7 January 1992|work=The New York Times|access-date=19 May 2016|via=}} From 1986 - 2016 her research has been conducted at [[Palmer Station|Palmer]] and [[McMurdo Station]]s, and aboard several research cruises in the [[Bellingshausen Sea]] and the [[Ross Sea]]. Since 1994 she has also been an instructor for the NSF advanced international integrative biology course taught at [[McMurdo Station]] and Palmer Station for early career scientists from across the world. She served for two years as the associate program manager for the Biology and Medicine Program at the U.S. [[National Science Foundation]] Office of Polar Programs. She has served as a U.S. representative to the Group on Life Sciences for the [[Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research]], and is currently the second US delegate to SCAR. She is also (since 2011) a private sector advisor for the US delegation to the Committee on Environmental Protection under the Antarctic Treaty System. == Awards and honors == An Antarctic ice-covered lake, Lake Karentz, was named after her in 2005 by the [[United States Board on Geographic Names|U.S. Board of Geographic Names]] in recognition of her contribution to the study of Antarctica.{{Cite web|url=http://geonames.usgs.gov/apex/f?p=136:3:0::NO::P3_ANTAR_ID,P3_TITLE:18744,Lake%2520Karentz|title=GNIS Detail - Lake Karentz|website=geonames.usgs.gov|access-date=2016-05-17}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.jamestownpress.com/news/2007-04-26/news/015.html|title=Antarctic lake named for scientist and former Jamestown resident|date=2007-04-26|website=www.jamestownpress.com|access-date=2016-05-17}}{{Cite web|url=http://mapcarta.com/25605794|title=Karentz, Lake|last=|first=|date=|website=Mapcarta|publisher=|access-date=19 May 2016}} In 1992 she was awarded the Luigi Provasoli Award for Outstanding Paper in the Journal of Phycology (1991-1992) from the Phycological Society of America for Karentz, D., J.E. Cleaver and D.M. Mitchell. 1991. Cell survival characteristics and molecular responses of Antarctic phytoplankton to ultraviolet-B radiation exposure. Journal of Phycology 27:326-341. == References == {{Reflist|35em}} == External links == *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pw2F58Q1ckc Sampling the Plankton Net] (video) {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Karentz, Deneb}} [[Category:University of San Francisco faculty]] [[Category:Marine biologists]] [[Category:Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

revision.text:
The '''Furupagha tribe''' is a small [[Ijaw people|Ijaw]] tribe that lives along the Siluko River in southwestern [[Edo State]], [[Nigeria]]. The town of Zide is the traditional clan seat.
The Furupagha trace their origins to the [[Bassan tribe|Bassan]] village of Furupagha in the central [[Niger Delta]].Alagoa, Ebiegberi Joe (2005). ''A History of the Niger Delta'', Port Harcourt: Onyoma Research Publications. {{ISBN|978-37314-5-9}}
==References== [[Category:Ijaw]] [[Category:Edo State]] {{Nigeria-ethno-group-stub}}

{{Infobox government agency |agency_name = General Directorate of Taxation |nativename = Drejtoria e Përgjithshme e Tatimeve |type = Revenue agency |logo = Drejtoria e Përgjithshme e Tatimeve.svg |logo_width = 125px |logo_caption = General Directorate of Taxation |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Albania]] |headquarters = [[Tirana]] |employees = |budget = |chief1_name = Vasilika Vjero |chief1_position = |child1_agency = |website = {{URL|http://www.tatime.gov.al}} |footnotes = }} The '''General Directorate of Taxation''' ({{sq|Drejtoria e Përgjithshme e Tatimeve}}) is a revenue collection agency of the [[Albanian Government]].
Its mission is to collect tax revenues through simple and minimal cost procedures, uniformly applying tax legislation to finance the Albanian state budget. To achieve these goals, the Directorate assists taxpayers with high quality services so they can fulfill their own tax obligations under the applicable legislation.
The administration is tasked to monitor, evaluate and penalize any conduct by the taxpayer who does not enforce or deliberately misappropriate the fulfillment of their legal obligations.<ref>[https://www.tatime.gov.al/c/8/42/68/rreth-administrates-tatimore-qendrore Rreth Administratës Tatimore Qendrore]</ref>
==See also== *[[Taxation in Albania]]
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Revenue services]] [[Category:Financial system of Albania]] [[Category:Finance agencies of Albania|Taxation]] [[Category:Albania stubs]] {{Albania-gov-stub}}

The '''Geneva Revolution of 1782''' was a short-lived attempt to broaden the franchise and include men of modest means in the republican government of the [[city state]].
In 1782 the constitution of the small city-state of Geneva limited the franchise to 1,500 well-to-do male burghers, (upper middle class citizens, mostly merchants.) About 5,000 lower middle-class ''natives,'' male Genevans born to long-standing Geneva families, lived in the city but were excluded from voting or serving in office. These men worked as artisans and craftsmen in various trades, principally watchmakers. Also excluded from the franchise were an even larger number of ''habitants,'' residents whose roots lay in the canton but outside the city, or whose families had immigrated to Geneva from elsewhere.<ref name=Polasky17>{{cite book|last1=[[Janet Polasky]]|title=[[Revolutions without Borders]]|date=2015|publisher=[[Yale University Press]]|isbn=978-0-300-20894-8|page=17}}</ref>
Agitation for a broader franchise had been ongoing for years; on 5 February 1781, unenfranchised men, ''habitants,'' and ''natives,'' broke into the municipal armory and armed themselves. In response, the General Council of Geneva, the largest of the city's legislative bodies, voted to grant voting rights to 100 ''natives'' and 20 ''habitants.'' However, the more elite legislative body, the Genevan Small Council, baulked at ratifying this token offer of enfranchisement, stalling for over a year before, in April 1782, voting to block the enfranchisement.<ref name=Polasky18>{{cite book|last1=[[Janet Polasky]]|title=[[Revolutions without Borders]]|date=2015|publisher=[[Yale University Press]]|isbn=978-0-300-20894-8|page=18}}</ref> Within hours of the vote, revolutionists occupied the City Hall, closed the city gates, held the "no voters (called ''Negatives'') hostage, and convinced the Representatives of the General Council to support them.<ref name=Polasky18/>
The city's wealthy burghers countered by persuading the [[Kingdom of France]], the city-state of [[Bern]], and the [[Kingdom of Sardinia]] to send professional troops. The leaders of the aborted Revolution fled by ship across Lake Geneva. The city was returned to government by the burgher elite.<ref name=Polasky18/>
==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} [[Category:Atlantic Revolutions]] [[Category:History of Geneva]] [[Category:18th-century revolutions]]
{{Switzerland-hist-stub}}

{{Infobox organization |name = |logo = [[File:Grévy's Zebra Trust.jpg|centre|200px]] ||type = [[Non-profit Organization]] |founded_date = Jan 2007 |founder = |location = |location_country = |area_served = [[Ethiopia]] and [[Kenya]] |origins = | key_people = Belinda Mackey (Executive Director) |focus = [[Grévy's Zebra]] Conservation |method = |revenue = |num_volunteers = |owner = |Non-profit_slogan = The Grévy's Zebra Trust conserves the endangered [[Grévy's Zebra]] and its fragile habitat in partnership with communities. |homepage = [http://www.grevyszebratrust.org/ grevyszebratrust.org] |dissolved = |footnotes = }}
The '''Grévy's Zebra Trust''' '''GZT''' was founded in 2007 for the protection of the [[Grévy's Zebra]]s (''Equus grevyi'') and their [[habitat]]. The Conservancy works to engage and incorporate local communities in protecting [[Grévy's Zebra]] in [[Ethiopia]] and [[Kenya]]. GZT uses scouts to collect scientific data, provide security, surveillance, and run education programs.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://wildlifeconservationnetwork.org/wildlife/zebra2.html#conservationist |title = Grévy's Zebra Trust |publisher = [[Wildlife Conservation Network]] }}</ref> Currently the Grévy's Zebras global population is today about 2,500 down from an estimated 15,000 in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.speciesconservation.org/projects/Grevys-Zebra/273 |title = Grevy’s Zebra (Equus grevyi) |publisher = The Mohamed Bin Zayed Species Conservation Fund}}</ref>
==Programs==
===Grevy's Zebra Scouts=== Grevy's Zebra scouts are locals who are hired and trained to help monitor the herds and report back data. The scouts also help share the message of conservation in their own communities.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://wildlifeconservationnetwork.org/wildlife/zebra2.html#conservationist |title = Grévy's Zebra Trust |publisher = [[Wildlife Conservation Network]] }}</ref>
===Holistic Rangeland Management=== Grévy's Zebra Trust works with communities to [[Rangeland management|manage grazing]] cattle to improve the land by tilling the land and fertilizing the land so that native grasses that the Zebras eat are better able to grow.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.treehugger.com/natural-sciences/novel-strategies-save-both-endangered-grevys-zebras-and-cattle-ranchers.html |title = Novel Strategies Save Both Endangered Grevy's Zebras and Cattle Ranchers |publisher = www.treehugger.com}}</ref>
===Grévy's Zebra Ambassadors=== Individuals from the Samburu and Turkana tribes that sometimes have conflict over resources are brought together to work with solutions to poaching and given jobs in data collection, security, surveillance and spreading the conservation message.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://ewasolions.wildlifedirect.org/2012/05/07/warriors-training/ |title = Training Warriors with Grevy’s Zebra Trust |publisher = Wildlife Direct}}</ref>
===Education and Outreach=== Teams of scouts go into the communities to perform conservation storytelling and puppet shows for local children and through workshops for the adults. In this process they strive to learn the needs of the communities.
==See also== {{Portal|Sustainable development|Environment|Ecology}} * [[Wildlife Conservation Network]] * [[Conservation movement]] * [[Environmental movement]] * [[Natural environment]] * [[Sustainability]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== {{Commons|Equus grevyi}} {{wikispecies|Equus grevyi}} * [http://www.grevyszebratrust.org/ grevyszebratrust.org], Grévy's Zebra Trust Website * [http://wildnet.org/ wildnet.org], [[Wildlife Conservation Network]] Website
{{DEFAULTSORT:Grevy's Zebra Trust}} [[Category:Endangered animals]] [[Category:International environmental organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2007]] [[Category:Zebras]] [[Category:Animal conservation organizations]] [[Category:Conservation projects]] [[Category:Mammal conservation]] [[Category:Animal welfare organisations based in Kenya]] [[Category:Animal welfare organisations based in Ethiopia]]

{{Infobox music festival | | music_festival_name = Interceltic Festival of Morrazo | image = | location = [[Moaña]], [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]] {{Flagicon|Galicia}}
[[Spain]] {{Flagicon|Spain}} | founders = Semente Nova | years_active= 1985 - present | dates = August each year. | genre = [[Folk music]] | website = [http://www.festivalinterceltico.com/ Official website] }} The '''Interceltic Festival of Morrazo''' is a folk music festival celebrated in August in [[Moaña]], in [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]] [[Spain]]. The purpose of the festival is to promote and develop traditional folk music, highlinting [[Celtic music]] and new tendencies. The festival was founded on the 15 August 1985 by the Semente Nova Bigpipes' School. ==External links== * [http://www.festivalinterceltico.com/ Official website] {{Music festivals in Spain}} [[Category:Music festivals in Spain]] [[Category:Celtic music festivals]] [[Category:Folk festivals in Spain]] {{Spain-stub}}

{{Infobox Organization |name = International Cotton Advisory Committee
Comité Consultatif International du Coton
Comité Consultivo Internacional del Algodón |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = [[#Member states|list of members]] |abbreviation = ICAC/CCIC/CCIA |motto = |formation = September 1939 |type = International commodity body |status = |purpose = Trade and production |headquarters = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Washington, DC]], [[United States of America]] |location = 1629 K Street NW, Suite 702, Washington, DC 20006 USA |region_served = World cotton industry |membership = 27 members |language = English, French, Spanish, summaries in Arabic and Russian |leader_title = Chair of the Standing Committee |leader_name = Mr Ali Tahir (''ad interim'') |main_organ = Standing Committee (4-5 meetings per year), ICAC Secretariat |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = Nine |num_volunteers = |budget = About US$2 million |website = [http://www.icac.org/ www.icac.org] |remarks = }} The '''International Cotton Advisory Committee''' ('''ICAC''') is an association of governments of [[cotton]] producing, consuming and trading countries which acts as the international commodity body for cotton and cotton textiles. ==Structure and history== Founded at the International Cotton Meeting in [[Washington, DC]] in 1939, the ICAC advocates for cotton producing nations, publishes studies and technical information on the cotton industry, and holds an annual Plenary Meeting of member states. While most of the world's cotton producing nations are members, two of the ten largest producers (The [[People's Republic of China]] and [[Turkmenistan]]) are not members of the ICAC. All of the top five cotton exporting nations are members. The International Cotton Advisory Committee (ICAC) along with private sector cotton organizations initiated the International Forum for Cotton Promotion (IFCP) in 2000. The IFCP serves as a forum and clearinghouse for the exchange of proven cotton promotion techniques. The IFCP facilitates domestically focused and domestically funded cotton promotion programs.{{Cite journal|last=A.|first=A.A. Terhaar Allen|date=2003-12-01|title=The international forum for cotton promotion|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/296236247_The_international_forum_for_cotton_promotion|volume=34|issue=12}} ==Member states== Member nations and date joining:[http://icac.org/general/facts/member_countries_september_2010.pdf member_countries_september_2010.pdf], icac.org # {{flag|Argentina}} May 1946 # {{flag|Australia}} May 1946 # {{flag|Bangladesh}} February 1917 # {{flag|Brazil}} September 1939 # {{flag|Burkina Faso}} October 1997 # {{flag|Chad}} March 1967 # {{flag|Cote d'Ivoire}} Auguast 1973 # {{flag|Egypt}} September 1939 # {{flag|European Union}} May 2017 # {{flag|India}} Sept 1939 # {{flag|Kazakhstan}} Sept 2006 # {{flag|Kenya}} July 2007 # {{flag|Korea}} (Republic of Korea) Mar 1954 # {{flag|Mali}} July 1996 # {{flag|Mozambique}} Sept 2010 # {{flag|Pakistan}} Jul 1948 # {{flag|Russia}} Feb 1962 (as [[USSR]]: Sept 1939) # {{flag|South Africa}} July 1991 # {{flag|Sudan}} Sept 1939 # {{flag|Switzerland}} Jan 1951 # {{flag|Taiwan}} Feb 1963 # {{flag|Togo}} Sept 1999 # {{flag|Turkey}} Nov 1947 # {{flag|Uganda}} Nov 1962 # {{flag|United States}} Sept 1939 # {{flag|Uzbekistan}} Sept 1992 # {{flag|Zimbabwe}} Apr 1991 ==See also== *[[Cotton#The international cotton trade|Cotton: The international cotton trade]] *Textile manufacturing- [[Textile manufacturing#Cotton|Machine processing of cotton]] *[[International Year of Natural Fibres]] ==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.icac.org/general/profile/english.html A Profile of the ICAC], icac.org [[Category:Organizations established in 1939]] [[Category:International economic organizations]] [[Category:1939 establishments in Washington, D.C.]]

{{Infobox radio station |name = 89.6 Radio DeeJay Ioannina |image = Ioannina_radio_deejay_logo.jpg |image_size = 200px |city = [[Ioannina]], [[Greece]] |area = [[Epirus (region)|Epirus]] |branding = '''Radio DeeJay''' |slogan = Mono epitixies gia ta Ioannina! |frequency = [[FM broadcasting|FM]]: 89.6 MHz |airdate = 1997 (MUSIC FM 89.6)
2009 (89.6 Radio DeeJay)
{{Start date|2009|09|09}} (current) |format = [[Contemporary hit radio|Top 40 (CHR)]] |language = [[Greek language|Greek]] |callsign_meaning = 89.6 Ioannina DeeJay |former_callsigns = Music FM 89.6 (1997–2009) |affiliations = '''95.2 Athens DeeJay''' |owner = Theocharis Tsitos
Lefteris Karagiorgos |website = {{URL|ioanninadeejay.gr}} }} '''Radio DeeJay Ioannina''' is a [[List of radio stations in Greece|radio station]] broadcasting on 89.6 MHz (stereo and RDS) serving [[Ioannina]], [[Epirus (region)|Epirus]] and the north-western portion of [[Greece]]. The station is a mixture of dance and [[Top 40]], much of the hits are [[Top 40]]. The station launched broadcasting on 9 September 2009, based on a 12-year course of Music FM. For the last 8 years, it is rebroadcasting '''95.2 Athens DeeJay''', but also gives listeners a rich and vibrant local radio program. Main audience covers the age groups 15–34, financially independent with high educational level, who reside in urban centers. The music program is determined by the current music trends in the international music scene, while promoting radio hits that will make a difference in the future. ==Slogan== Its slogan is ''Mono epitixies gia ta Ioannina!'' (Hits only, for Ioannina!) ==External links== *[http://www.ioanninadeejay.gr/idj/ Official website] *[http://50.7.130.2:7546/ Live streaming] {{coord missing|Greece}} [[Category:Radio stations in Greece]] [[Category:Media in Ioannina]] {{Europe-radio-station-stub}} {{Greece-stub}}

{{Infobox officeholder |name = Jan Marijnissen |image = Marijnissen2006.jpg |caption = Jan Marijnissen in 2006 |office = [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|Member of the House of Representatives]] |term_start = 17 May 1994 |term_end = 17 June 2010 |parliamentarygroup = [[Socialist Party (Netherlands)|Socialist Party]] |office1 = [[Parliamentary leader]] in the [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]] |term_start1 = 17 May 1994 |term_end1 = 20 June 2008 |predecessor1 = ''New title'' |successor1 = [[Agnes Kant]] |parliamentarygroup1= [[Socialist Party (Netherlands)|Socialist Party]] |office2 = [[Socialist Party (Netherlands)#Leadership|Chairman of the Socialist Party]] |term_start2 = 20 May 1988 |term_end2 = 28 November 2015 |predecessor2 = [[Hans van Hooft]] |successor2 = [[Ron Meyer (politician)|Ron Meyer]] |office3 = [[Leader of the Socialist Party (Netherlands)|Leader of the Socialist Party]] |term_start3 = 1 October 1986 |term_end3 = 20 June 2008 |predecessor3 = [[Daan Monjé]] |successor3 = [[Agnes Kant]] |birthname = Johannes Guillaume Christianus Andreas Marijnissen |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1952|10|08|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Oss]], [[Netherlands]] |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = [[Netherlands|Dutch]] |party = [[Socialist Party (Netherlands)|Socialist Party]] (from 1972) |otherparty = [[Communist Unity Movement of the Netherlands (Marxist–Leninist)|Communist Unity Movement of the Netherlands]] (1970–1972) |spouse = {{marriage|Mari-Anne van Schijndel|1976}} |children = [[Lilian Marijnissen]] (born 1985) |residence = [[Oss]], [[Netherlands]] |alma_mater = |occupation = [[Politician]] · [[Welder]] · [[Activism|Activist]] · [[Author]] · [[Columnist]] |signature = |website = {{nl icon}} [http://www.janmarijnissen.nl/ Official website] }} '''Johannes Guillaume Christianus Andreas "Jan" Marijnissen''' ({{Audio|Nl-Jan Marijnissen.ogg|Jan Marijnissen}}) (born 8 October 1952) is a retired [[Netherlands|Dutch]] politician of the [[Socialist Party (Netherlands)|Socialist Party]] (SP). Marijnissen a [[welder]] by occupation, was selected as [[Leader of the Socialist Party (Netherlands)|Leader of the Socialist Party]] after the death of [[Daan Monjé]] on 1 October 1986 and became [[Socialist Party (Netherlands)#Leadership|Chairman of the Socialist Party]] on 20 May 1988. For the [[Dutch general election, 1994|election of 1994]] Marijnissen was the [[Lijsttrekker]] (top candidate) and won two seats in the [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]], the first time the [[Socialist Party (Netherlands)|Socialist Party]] won representation in the [[States General of the Netherlands]]. Marijnissen was elected as a [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|Member of the House of Representatives]] on 17 May 1994 and became the [[Parliamentary leader]] of the [[Socialist Party (Netherlands)|Socialist Party]] in the [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]]. For the [[Dutch general election, 1998|elections of 1998]] and [[Dutch general election, 2002|2002]] Marijnissen again as [[Lijsttrekker]] won three and four seats respectively. For the [[Dutch general election, 2006|election of 2006]] Marijnissen for the fifth time as [[Lijsttrekker]] won sixteen seats and the [[Socialist Party (Netherlands)|Socialist Party]] became the third-largest party [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]]. On 20 June 2008 Marijnissen announced his retirement as [[Leader of the Socialist Party (Netherlands)|Leader of the Socialist Party]] and [[Parliamentary leader]] of the [[Socialist Party (Netherlands)|Socialist Party]] in the [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]] citing health reasons. Marijnissen remained a [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|Member of the House of Representatives]] until after the [[Dutch general election, 2010|2010 general election]]. Marijnissen stood down as [[Socialist Party (Netherlands)#Leadership|Chairman of the Socialist Party]] on 28 November 2015. He is the father of [[Lilian Marijnissen]], the current [[Leader of the Socialist Party (Netherlands)|Leader of the Socialist Party]]. ==Early life== Johannes Guillaume Christianus Andreas Marijnissen was born on 8 October 1952 in [[Oss]] in the [[Provinces of the Netherlands|Dutch Province]] of [[North Brabant]] in a [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] family. After leaving secondary school shortly before the exams, he worked in a number of factories in and around [[Oss]]. He then trained as a welder, working for ten years in the metal industry. ==Politics== ===Local politics=== Meanwhile, he helped founding the SP in Oss and, in 1975, became the Netherlands' youngest councillor ever. He remained a councillor until 1993, playing a leading role in many campaigns, such as against polluting discharges. The SP's council representation in Oss has grown at every local election and is, as of 2005, the biggest stronghold of the Socialist Party in the Netherlands. Nicknamed "The Wizard of Oss", after his hometown, he became famous when he turned out to be one of the main architects of the Dutch vote that rejected the [[European Constitution]] in June 2005. In 1987 Marijnissen became the party's first ever [[States-Provincial|provincial]] assembly member, in [[North Brabant]]. A year later he became the SP's national president. Under his leadership the party was transformed from "a federation of local branches" into a party with a clear national programme, nationally-organised activities and a national profile. ===National politics=== Beginning in 1994, when the SP made the breakthrough which brought it into the [[House of Representatives of the Netherlands|House of Representatives]], Marijnissen was chairman of the party's parliamentary group. After gaining two out of the 150 parliamentary seats during this first breakthrough, support for him and his party rose slowly but continuously. After four years in parliament, his Socialist Party went under his lead from two to five seats during the [[Dutch general election, 1998|national elections of 1998]], which was followed by a growth towards nine seats in 2002. In 2003, after the 87-day term of [[First Balkenende cabinet|Balkenende I]], the Socialist Party didn't manage to gain more seats than the year before and stayed at the same level with again 9 out of 150 seats. Although there was a slight rise in number of people who voted for the SP compared to a year before, a few weeks before the elections the polls suggested the SP might double. After the 2004 elections a conflict arose between Jan Marijnissen and [[Ali Lazrak]], when the latter refused to conform to an agreement that required all SP politicians to donate part of their wages. Lazrak accused Marijnissen of dictatorial behavior; an attempt to settle the argument failed and Lazrak left the [[fraction (politics)|fraction]] on 2 February 2004. In February 2006 the party was polled on 9.5% of the electorate in the [[Dutch municipal elections, 2006|municipal elections]]. After the untimely end of [[Second Balkenende cabinet|Balkenende II]] and the minority government of [[Third Balkenende cabinet|Balkenende III]], the SP won 16 more seats in the [[Dutch general election, 2006|2006 elections]] to a total of 25, becoming the third party of the Netherlands. Soon after, the party membership passed 50,000.[http://www.janmarijnissen.nl/2006/11/29/50000-2/ Jan Marijnissen verwelkomt 50.000ste SP-lid met taart en bloemen]. Downloaded November 29, 2005 In 2006 a majority of members of parliament voted for his idea to build a National Historic Museum in the Netherlands. In 2007 the Minister of Culture decided the city [[Arnhem]] would be its residence. On 17 June 2008 Marijnissen announced his resignation as chairman of the SP group in the House of Representatives because of health reasons.{{cite web|url=http://www.trouw.nl/hetnieuws/nederland/article1015335.ece/Marijnissen_vertrekt_als_SP-fractievoorzitter|title=Cookies op Trouw.nl|work=trouw.nl}} However, he remains a member of the House of Representatives and chairman of the Socialist Party. Marijnissen was said to appeal to the 'common man' because of his use of simple language. His appeal is also explained by some observers by his capacity of presenting himself as a valid, more social alternative to the [[Dutch Labour Party|PvdA]], which moved into a more centrist [[Third Way (centrism)|third way]] direction by advocating welfare reforms under the leadership of Prime Minister [[Wim Kok]] and his so-called Purple Cabinets (1994–2002). Critics of Marijnissen call his leadership style authoritarian, because he is presumed to have a tight grip on his party. ==Bibliography== *''[http://www.janmarijnissen.nl/boeken/samenleven-inhoud.stm Samenleven kan je niet alleen]'' (You can't live together alone), SP, (1993). ({{ISBN|90-801777-1-7}}) *''[http://www.janmarijnissen.nl/boeken/tegenstemmen_inhoud.stm Tegenstemmen, een rood antwoord op Paars]'' (Voting against, a red answer to Purple), (Amsterdam/Antwerp: L.J. Veen, 1996). ({{ISBN|90-254-0860-5}}). This book is also available in English under the title ''[http://international.sp.nl/publications/ Enough! A socialist bites back]''. In 2006 three new English chapters were added with summaries of conclusion in his latter books. In 2007 the book became available in Greece under the title ''[http://www.monthlyreview.gr/antilogos/greek/ekdoseis/fullstory_html?obj_path=docrep/docs/ekdoseis/enough_marijnissen/gr/html/index Αρκετά!]''. (Athens: Antilogos, 2007). ({{ISBN|978-960-89490-4-1}}) *''[http://www.janmarijnissen.nl/boeken/effedimmen_inhoud.stm Effe Dimmen! Een rebel in Den Haag]''. (Amsterdam/Antwerp: L.J. Veen, 1998). ({{ISBN|90-204-5766-7}}). *''[http://www.janmarijnissen.nl/boeken/delaatsteoorlog_inhoud.stm De laatste oorlog: Gesprekken over de nieuwe wereldorde]'' (The last war), (Amsterdam/Antwerp: L.J. Veen, 2000). ({{ISBN|90-204-6022-6}}). Co-authored with Karel Glastra van Loon. A series of interviews with experts as Lord Carrington, Sir Michael Rose, Hans van den Broek, Noam Chomsky, Rob de Wijk en [[Georgi Arbatov]] on international conflicts with special attention to the role of the Dutch in these conflicts. *''[http://www.janmarijnissen.nl/boeken/schralerijkdom_inhoud.stm Schrale Rijkdom: De erfenis van acht jaar Paars]'' (Poor Richness), (Ketch-up Press, 2002). ({{ISBN|90-77133-01-1}}). *''[http://www.janmarijnissen.nl/boeken/nieuwoptimisme_inhoud.shtml Nieuw Optimisme]'' (New Optimism), (Aspekt, 2003). *''Hoe dan, Jan'' (But how, Jan?), (Amsterdam/Antwerp: L.J. Veen, 2005). Two Dutch journalist wrote a question/ answer style book about how Marijnissen's ideas could become reality. *''Waar historie huis houdt'' (Where history lives), (Rap, 2005). In addition to his plea for a National Historic Museum for the Netherlands, Jan Marijnissen reveals his interest in history and the importance of history to a land and its culture. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== ;Official * {{nl icon}} [http://www.parlement.com/id/vg09lllgjnqh/j_g_ch_a_jan_marijnissen J.G.Ch.A. (Jan) Marijnissen] Parlement & Politiek {{Commons category}} {{s-start}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Daan Monjé]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Leader of the Socialist Party (Netherlands)|Leader of the Socialist Party]]|years=1986–2008}} {{s-aft|after=[[Agnes Kant]]}} {{s-bef|before=[[Hans van Hooft]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Socialist Party (Netherlands)#Leadership|Chairman of the Socialist Party]]|years=1988–2015}} {{s-aft|after=[[Ron Meyer (politician)|Ron Meyer]]}} {{s-new}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Parliamentary leader]] of the [[Socialist Party (Netherlands)|Socialist Party]]
in the [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives of the Netherlands]]|years=1994–2008}} {{s-aft|after=[[Agnes Kant]]}} {{end}} {{Members of the House of Representatives of the Netherlands, 2006–2010}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Marijnissen, Jan}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Anti-globalization writers]] [[Category:Anti-globalization activists]] [[Category:Dutch agnostics]] [[Category:Dutch bloggers]] [[Category:Dutch columnists]] [[Category:Dutch political writers]] [[Category:Dutch political activists]] [[Category:Dutch republicans]] [[Category:Former Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Marxist writers]] [[Category:Metalworkers]] [[Category:Moldmakers]] [[Category:Foundrymen]] [[Category:Smelters (occupation)]] [[Category:Members of the House of Representatives (Netherlands)]] [[Category:Members of the Provincial-Council of North Brabant]] [[Category:Municipal councillors in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Chairmen of the Socialist Party (Netherlands)]] [[Category:Leaders of the Socialist Party (Netherlands)]] [[Category:People from Oss]] [[Category:Socialist Party (Netherlands) politicians]] [[Category:Writers about globalization]] [[Category:Writers about communism]] [[Category:Writers about activism and social change]] [[Category:21st-century Dutch politicians]]

revision.text:
'''Kaskazi''' is a name used to refer to an ancient ethno-linguistic group of [[Bantu peoples]] which took shape in the [[East African Rift|Western Rift]] area in the early centuries of the last millennium BC within the [[Mashariki people|Mashariki group]]. The name comes from the [[swahili language|swahili]] word for "northern wind", in opposition to the [[Kusi people|Kusi]] subgroup ("southern wind"). The Kaskazi subgroup settled north of [[Mozambique]] and [[Malawi]], while the Kusi settled in the south.<ref>Ehret (1998), p. 35</ref> Both the Kaskazi and Kusi did not form as single communities with a single language, but as clusters of communities speaking a variety of slightly different languages.<ref>Ehret (1998), p. 33</ref>
==Footnotes== <references/>
==References== Christopher Ehret (1998), ''An African Classical Age'', University of Virginia Press, {{ISBN|0813918146}}.
[[Category:Bantu languages]]
{{Africa-hist-stub}} {{Bantu-lang-stub}}

{{italic title}} {{Chinese|collapse=no |title='''A Map of the Myriad Countries of the World''' |t=坤輿萬國全圖 |s=坤舆万国全图 |p=Kūnyú Wànguó Quántú |bpmf=ㄎㄨㄣㄩˊ ㄨㄢˋㄍㄨㄛˊ ㄑㄩㄢˊㄊㄨˊ |poj=khun-î bān-kok tsuân-tôo |wuu=khuen<sup>平</sup> yiu<sup>平</sup> vae<sup>去</sup> koh<sup>入</sup> zie<sup>平</sup> du<sup>平</sup> |j=kwan<sup>1</sup> jyu<sup>4</sup> maan<sup>6</sup> gwok<sup>3</sup> cyun<sup>4</sup> tou<sup>4</sup> |h=kun<sup>24</sup> i<sup>11</sup> van<sup>55</sup> gued<sup>2</sup> qion<sup>11</sup> tu<sup>11</sup> |buc=<!--Will be added later.--> |kanji=坤輿万国全図 |kyujitai=坤輿萬國全圖 |kana=こんよばんこくぜんず |romaji=Kon'yo Bankoku Zenzu |hangul=곤여만국전도 |hanja=坤輿萬國全圖 |rr=Gonyeo Manguk Jeondo |qn=Khôn Dư Vạn Quốc Toàn Đồ |hn=<!--To be used after the release of the next Unicode update of CJK Extensions.--> |lang2=Italian |lang2_content=Carta Geografica Completa di tutti i Regni del Mondo }} '''''Kunyu Wanguo Quantu''''' ({{zh|c=坤輿萬國全圖|p=Kūnyú Wànguó Quántú|l=A Map of the Myriad Countries of the World}}; {{lang-it|Carta Geografica Completa di tutti i Regni del Mondo}}, "Complete Geographical Map of all the Kingdoms of the World"), printed in China at the request of the [[Wanli Emperor]] during 1602 by the [[Italians|Italian]] [[Catholic]] missionary [[Matteo Ricci]] and Chinese collaborators, Mandarin Zhong Wentao and the technical translator, [[Li Zhizao#Li Zhizao|Li Zhizao]], is the earliest known [[Classical Chinese|Chinese]] [[world map]] with the style of [[Europe]]an maps.<ref name="Baran">{{cite news|url=http://minnesota.publicradio.org/display/web/2009/12/16/tulip-map/|title=Historic map coming to Minnesota |last=Baran|first=Madeleine |date=December 16, 2009|publisher=Minnesota Public Radio|accessdate=12 January 2010|location=St. Paul, Minn. }}</ref> It has been referred to as the ''Impossible [[Tulip mania|Black Tulip]] of [[Cartography]]'', "because of its rarity, importance and exoticism".<ref name="Abbe">{{cite news|url=http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/art/79576487.html|title=Million-dollar map coming to Minnesota|last=Abbe|first=Mary|date=2009-12-18|work= Star Tribune|publisher=Star Tribune Company|accessdate=12 January 2010|location=Minneapolis}}</ref> The map was crucial in expanding [[China|Chinese]] knowledge of the world. It was eventually exported to [[Joseon|Korea]]<ref name=park>{{citation |last=Park |first=Seongrae |contribution=The Introduction of Western Science in Korea: A Comparative View with the Cases of China and Japan |contribution-url=http://ci.nii.ac.jp/els/contentscinii_20170517194941.pdf?id=ART0007572705 |title=Northeast Asian Studies |volume=Vol. 4 |date=2000 |pp=32 }}.</ref> then [[Tokugawa Shogunate|Japan]] and was influential there as well,<ref>''Japan and China: mutual representations in the modern era'' Wataru Masuda p.17 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Qh8ueI1OLEEC&pg=PA17]</ref> though less so than [[Julius Alenius|Alenio]]'s ''[[Zhifang Waiji]]''.
==Description== {{multiple image | width = 250 | footer = ''Kunyu Wanguo Quantu'', printed by [[Matteo Ricci]], Zhong Wentao and [[Li Zhizao#Li Zhizao|Li Zhizao]], upon request of [[Wanli Emperor]] in Beijing, 1602 | image1 = Kunyu Wanguo Quantu by Matteo Ricci Plate 1-3.jpg | caption1 = Left panels 1-3 | image2 = Kunyu Wanguo Quantu by Matteo Ricci Plate 4-6.jpg | caption2 = Right panels 4-6 }}
[[File:Kunyu Wanguo Quantu (坤輿萬國全圖).jpg|thumb|505px|right|Unattributed (1604?), two page colored Japanese copy of the 1602 map]] [[File:Map projection-Eckert IV.png|thumb|300px|Pseudocylindrical Eckert IV map projection, 1906, resembling the 1602 Ricci map]] The 1602 Ricci map is a very large, {{convert|5|ft|abbr=on|2}} high and {{convert|12|ft|abbr=on|2}} wide, [[woodcut]] using a [[Map projection#Pseudocylindrical|pseudocylindrical map projection]] showing [[China]] at the center of the known world.<ref name="Abbe"/> The 1906 Eckert IV map resembles the display of this Chinese map. It is the first map in Chinese to show the [[Americas]]. The map's [[mirror image]] originally was carved on six large blocks of wood and then [[Woodblock printing|printed]] in brownish ink on six mulberry paper panels, similar to the making of a [[folding screen]].
It portrays both [[North America|North]] and [[South America]] and the [[Pacific Ocean]] with reasonable accuracy. China appropriately is linked to [[Asia]], [[India]], and the [[Middle East]]. [[Europe]], the [[Mediterranean]], and [[Africa]] also are well delineated.<ref name="Abbe"/> Diane Neimann, a trustee of the James Ford Bell Trust, notes that: "There is some distortion, but what's on the map is the result of commerce, trade and exploration, so one has a good sense of what was known then."<ref name="Abbe"/>
Ti Bin Zhang, first secretary for cultural affairs at the Chinese Embassy in [[Washington, D.C.]], said in 2009: "The map represents the momentous first meeting of East and West" and was the "catalyst for commerce."<ref name="CBC">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/artdesign/story/2010/01/12/rare-map-china-world.html|title=Rare map puts China at centre of world|date=12 January 2010|work=CBC News|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Centre|accessdate=12 January 2010|location=Toronto}}</ref>
==Details== [[File:World map-impossible black tulip-small.jpg|thumb|Small scale north polar projection world map at the top of the first left panel of 1602 Ricci map]] [[File:Sancai Tuhui World Map.jpg|thumb|1609 [[Shanhai Yudi Quantu]] (not by Ricci)]] [[File:JesuitChineseWorldMapEarly17thCentury.jpg|thumb|1620s [[Giulio Aleni]] world map ''[[Wanguo Quantu]]'' (萬國全圖),<ref>Wigal, p.202</ref>]] [[File:Kunyu Quantu of Ferdinand Verbiest 1674.jpg|thumb|1674 ''Kunyu Quantu'' of Ferdinand Verbiest 2 hemispheres]] [[File:Kunyu Quantu Ferdinand Verbiest 1674.jpg|thumb|1674 ''Kunyu Quantu'' by Ferdinand Verbiest 1 hemisphere (very detailed)]] [[File:Impossible Black Tulip-world map, 6 panels.jpg|thumb|James Ford Bell Library copy of 1602 Ricci map]] [[File:Impossible Black Tulip- World map, panels 1&6 Bologna.jpg|thumb|Museo della Specola, Bologna copy, panels 1 and 6 (left & right)]] The map includes images and annotations describing different regions of the world. Africa is noted to have the world's highest mountain and longest river. The brief description of North America mentions "humped oxen" or [[bison]] (駝峰牛 ''tuófēngníu''), [[feral horse]]s (野馬, ''yěmǎ''), and names [[Canada]] (加拿大, ''Jiānádà''). The map identifies [[Florida]] as ''Huādì'' (花地), the "Land of Flowers." Several Central and South American places are named, including [[Guatemala]] (哇的麻剌, ''Wādemálá''), [[Yucatan]] (宇革堂, ''Yǔgétáng''), and [[Chile]] (智里, ''Zhīlǐ'').<ref name="CBC"/>
The map's [[cartographer]], Matteo Ricci, gave a brief description of the discovery of the Americas. "In olden days, nobody had ever known that there were such places as North and South America or [[Magellanica]] (using [[Terra Australis|a name]] that early mapmakers gave to a supposed continent including Australia, Antarctica, and [[Tierra del Fuego]]), but a hundred years ago, Europeans came sailing in their ships to parts of the sea coast, and so discovered them."<ref name="CBC"/>
The Museo della Specola [[Bologna]] has in its collection, displayed on the wall of the Globe Room, original copies of panels 1 and 6 of the six panels comprising the 1602 Ricci map. During restoration and mounting, a central panel—a part of the Doppio Emisfero delle Stelle by the German mathematician and astronomer [[Johann Adam Schall von Bell]]—was inserted between the two sections by mistake.
In 1958, Pasquale D’Elia, sinologist at the [[Sapienza University of Rome|University of Rome]] certified the authenticity of the Chinese maps in this museum’s possession, (see op. cit.) stating that "it is the third edition of a geographical and cartographical work that made Ricci famous throughout China. He had already made a first edition in 1584 at Shiuhing, followed by a second in 1600 at [[Nanking]], and two years later a third in Peking.<ref name="Battistini"/>
In 1938, an exhaustive work by Pasquale d'Elia, edited by the Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana, was published with comments, notes, and translation of the whole map.<ref name="d'Elia">{{cite book|last=d' Elia|first= Pasquale M.|title= Il mappamondo cinese del P Matteo Ricci, S.I. (3. ed., Pechino, 1602) conservato presso la Biblioteca Vaticana, commentato tradotto e annotato dal p. Pasquale M. d'Elia, S. I. ... Con XXX tavole geografiche e 16 illustrazioni fuori testo ...|year=1938|publisher=Città del Vaticano, Biblioteca apostolica Vaticana|accessdate=14 January 2010|location=Vatican|oclc= 84361232| url=http://searchworks.stanford.edu/view/1840821}}</ref> The maps carry plentiful instructions for use and detailed illustrations of the instruments that went into their production, as well as explanations regarding conceptions of "systems of the terrestrial and celestial world".<ref name="Battistini">{{cite web|url=http://www.bo.astro.it/dip/Museum/english/car_65.html|title=65. Geographical map by Matteo Ricci|last=Battistini|first=Pierluigi|date=1997-08-26|work=Museo della Specola, Catalogue, maps|publisher=University of Bologna|accessdate=14 January 2010|location=Bologna}}</ref> There is a long preface by Matteo Ricci in the middle of the map, where it depicts the Pacific Ocean. D’Elia’s translation reads:
{{quotation|"Once I thought learning was a multifold experience and I would not refuse to travel [even] ten thousand Li to be able to question wise men and visit celebrated countries. But how long is a man’s life? It is certain that many years are needed to acquire a complete science, based on a vast number of observations: and that’s where one becomes old without the time to make use of this science. Is this not a painful thing? And this is why I put great store by [geographical] maps and history: history for fixing [these observations], and maps for handing them on [to future generations].
Respectfully written by the European Matteo Ricci on 17 August 1602."}}
The figure of the ''Nove Cieli'' (Nine Skies) is printed to the left of the title, illustrated as per sixteenth-century conceptions. The accompanying inscription explains the movement of the planets. The right-hand section (panel 6) has other inscriptions giving general ideas on geography and oceanography. Another inscription records an extract of the Storia dei Mongoli regarding the motions of the Sun. In the top of the left-hand section (panel 1), there is an explanation of eclipses and the method for measuring the Earth and the Moon. Both sections carry the characteristic Jesuit seal, the [[Holy Name of Jesus|IHS]] of the [[Society of Jesus]]. At the bottom left, in the [[Southern Hemisphere]], is the name of the Chinese [[publisher]] of the map and the date: ''one day of the first month of autumn in the year 1602''.<ref name="Battistini"/>
The map also incorporates an explanation of parallels and meridians, a proof that the sun is larger than the moon, a table showing the distances of planets from the earth, an explanation of the varying lengths of days and nights, and polar projections of the earth that are unusually consistent with its main map.<ref name="Rothstein"/>
==History== [[Matteo Ricci]] (1552–1610) was a [[Society of Jesus|Jesuit]] priest. Ricci was one of the first Western scholars to live in China and he became a master of Chinese script and the Classical Chinese language. In 1583, Ricci was among the first Jesuits to enter China from Macao. The first Chinese world map was named ''Yudi Shanhai Quantu'' (輿地山海全圖) and made in [[Zhaoqing]] in 1584 by Matteo Ricci with Chinese collaborators.<ref name="Elman"/> Ricci had a small Italian wall map in his possession and created Chinese versions of it at the request of the governor of Zhaoqing at the time, Wang Pan, who wanted the document to serve as a resource for explorers and scholars.<ref name="regents"/>
On January 24, 1601, Ricci was the first Jesuit - and one of the first Westerners - to enter the [[Ming Dynasty|Ming]] capital [[Beijing]],<ref name="Battistini"/> bringing atlases of Europe and the West that were unknown to his hosts. The Chinese had maps of the East that were equally unfamiliar to Western scholars.
In 1602, at the request of the [[Wanli Emperor]], Ricci collaborated with Mandarin Zhong Wentao, a technical translator, [[Li Zhizao#Li Zhizao|Li Zhizao]],<ref name="Elman">{{cite book|last=Elman|first=Benjamin A. |title=On their own terms: science in China, 1550–1900|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, MA|date=April 2005|pages=127-Matteo Mundi's ''Mappa Mundi''|chapter=Sin0-Jesuit Accommodations During the Seventeenth Century|isbn=978-0-674-01685-9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KPEpPhlzPg0C&pg=PA127#v=onepage&q=&f=false}}</ref> and other Chinese scholars in Beijing to create what was his third and largest world map, the ''Kunyu Wanguo Quantu''.<ref name="regents"/>
In this map, European geographic knowledge, new to the Chinese, was combined with Chinese information unknown to Europeans to create the first map known to combine Chinese and European cartography.<ref name="regents"/> Among other things, this map revealed the existence of America to the Chinese. Ford W. Bell said: "This was a great collaboration between East and West. It really is a very clear example of how trade was a driving force behind the spread of civilization."
According to John D. Day,<ref name="Day">John D. Day, “The Search for the Origins of the Chinese Manuscripts of Matteo Ricci’s Maps”, ''Imago Mundi'' 47 (1995), pp. 94–117</ref> Matteo Ricci prepared four editions of Chinese world maps during his [[Jesuit China missions#Ricci.27s policy of accommodation|mission in China]] before 1603: # a 1584 early woodblock print made in Zhaoqing, called ''Yudi Shanhai Quantu''; # a 1596 map carved on a [[stele]], called ''Shanhai Yudi Tu'' (山海輿地圖); # a 1600 revised version of the 1596, usually named ''Shanhai Yudi Quantu'' (山海輿地全圖), engraved by Wu Zhongming; # a 1602 larger and much refined edition of the 1584 map, in six panels, printed in Beijing, called ''Kunyu Wanguo Quantu'';<ref name="Day"/>{{#tag:ref|Hong Weilian, earlier established a list of twelve total Ricci maps, which differs from Day’s findings.}}<ref name="Kao">“Kao Li Madou de shijie ditu”, p. 28</ref><ref name="Ptak"/>
Several prints of the Kunyu Wanguo Quantu were made in 1602. Most of the original maps now are lost. Only six original copies of the map are known to exist, and only two are in good condition. Known copies are in the [[Vatican Library|Vatican]] Apostolic Library Collection I and at the [[James Ford Bell Library]] at the University of Minnesota. The Vatican's 1602 copy was reproduced by Pasquale d’Elia in the beautifully arranged book, ''Il mappamondo cinese del P Matteo Ricci, S.I.'' in 1938. This modern work also contains Italian translations of the [[Colophon (publishing)|colophon]]s on the map, a catalogue of all [[toponym]]s, plus detailed notes regarding their identification.<ref name="Day"/><ref name="Mappa">''Mappamondo''. For earlier English translations of some of the colophons, see, for example, Lionel Giles, “Translations from the Chinese World Map of Father Ricci”, ''Geographical Journal'' 52 (1918), pp. 367–385; and 53 (1919), pp. 19–30.</ref>
Other copies of the 1602 map are located at: Japan, [[Kyoto University]] Collection; collection of Japan [[Miyagi Prefecture]] Library; Collection of the Library of the [[Japanese Cabinet]]; and a private collection in Paris, France.<ref name="Abbe"/><ref name="regents">{{cite web|url=http://bell.lib.umn.edu/RicciMap1.html|title=The James Ford Bell Library to Unveil Ricci Map on January 12|year=2009|work=James Ford Bell Library|publisher=Regents of the University of Minnesota|accessdate=13 January 2010|location=Minneapolis}}</ref> No original examples of the map are known to exist in China, where Ricci was revered and buried.<ref name="CBC"/>
The maps received widespread attention and circulation. The governor General of Guizhou reproduced a copy of the map in a book about Guizhou published in Guiyang in 1604. Ricci estimated that more than 1,000 copies of the 1602 edition were reprinted.<ref name="Hostetler">{{cite book|last=Hostetler|first=Laura|title=Qing Colonial Enterprise: Ethnography and Cartography in Early Modern China |publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago|year=2001|pages=52–54|chapter=Two- Mapping Territory|isbn=978-0-226-35420-0 |oclc=61477717|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8UKTzo1UiVgC&pg=PA52}}</ref>
Various versions of the map were exported to [[Korea]] and later [[Japan]]. The first Korean copy was brought back from Beijing by visiting ambassadors in 1603.<ref name=park/> An unattributed and very detailed two page coloured edition of the map, known in Japanese as ''Konyo Bankoku Zenzu'', was made in Japan circa 1604. Within this Japanese export copy, Japanese [[Katakana]] is utilised for foreign location names throughout the Western world.
The ''Gonyeomangukjeondo'' ([[Hangul]]: 곤여만국전도) is a [[Korea]]n hand-copied reproduction print by Painter [[Kim Jin-yeo]] in 1708, the 34th year of [[Sukjong of Joseon|King Sukjong's]] rule of [[Joseon]]. It shows Kunyu Wanguo Quantu (Complete Map of the World) measuring 533×170 cm on mulberry paper. This map, representing the world in an ellipse, was brought to Korea in the 36th year of King Seonjo's rule (1710) by Lee Gwan-jeong and Gwon Hui, two envoys of Joseon to China. It is owned and displayed at [[Seoul National University]] Museum, San 56-1, Sillim-dong, Gwanak-gu, [[Seoul]], Korea and was designated National Treasure No.849 on August 9, 1985. The map shows five world continents and over 850 toponyms. It contains descriptions of ethnic groups and main products associated with each region. In the margins outside the ellipse, there are images of the northern and southern hemispheres, the [[Aristotel]]ian [[geocentric]] world system, and the orbits of the sun and moon. It has an introduction by Choe Seok-jeong providing information on the constitution of the map and its production process. This reproduction map provides a clear testimony to the national interest in western maps in 17th-century Korea. It is a highly esthetic piece of work and one of the most beautiful maps produced during the Joseon period.<ref name="Seoul">{{cite web|url=http://sca.seoul.go.kr/english/culturalAsset.jsp?sClssCode=2&sClssCode2=10|title=Gonyeomangukjeondo (Kunyu Wanguo Quantu; Complete Map of the World)|work=Cultural History of Seoul|publisher=Seoul Metropolitan Government|accessdate=15 March 2010}}</ref>
==Bell Library copy== The [[James Ford Bell Trust]] announced in December 2009 that it had acquired one of two good copies of the 1602 Ricci map from the firm of [[Bernard J. Shapero]], a noted dealer of rare books and maps in London, for US$1 million, the second most expensive map purchase in history. This copy had been held for years by a private collector in Japan.<ref name="CBC"/>
Ford W. Bell, president of the American Association of Museums (now the [[American Alliance of Museums]]) and a trustee of the James Ford Bell Trust started by his grandfather, [[James Ford Bell]], the founder of [[General Mills]], said in an interview with a reporter from [[Minnesota Public Radio]]'s ''[[All Things Considered]]'': "These opportunities don't present themselves very often. This map was the only one on the market, and the only one likely to be on the market. So we had to take advantage of that opportunity."<ref name="Baran"/>
The map was displayed for the first time in North America at the [[Library of Congress]] from January through April, 2010. It was [[Image scanner|scanned]] by the Library of Congress Geography and Map Division to create a permanent [[digital image]] that will be posted on the [[internet]] later in 2010 in the [[World Digital Library]] for scholars and students to study. The map was then exhibited briefly at the [[Minneapolis Institute of Arts]], before moving to its permanent home at the [[James Ford Bell Library]] at the [[University of Minnesota]], where it will be on display beginning September 15, 2010.<ref name="Baran"/><ref name="Urschel">{{cite news|url=https://www.loc.gov/today/pr/2010/10-002.html|title=Rare 1602 World Map, the First Map in Chinese to Show the Americas, on Display at Library of Congress, Jan. 12 to April 10|last=Urschel|first=Donna|date=12 January 2010|work=News from the Library of Congress|publisher=Library of Congress|accessdate=12 January 2010|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref>
==Chinese maps published after 1602== Before his death at Peking in 1610, Matteo Ricci prepared four more world maps after the 1602 one: :5. a 1603 eight panel version of the 1602 map, usually named ''Liangyi Xuanlan Tu'' (兩儀玄覽圖) (Map for the far-reaching observation of heaven and earth). The 1603 edition is larger than the 1602, but is less well known because of the fewer extant copies and versions based on it;<ref name="Chen"/> :6. a 1604 booklet based on the map of 1600, also named ''Shanhai Yudi Quantu''; engraved by Guo Zizhang (郭子章); :7. a new 1608 version, twelve copies presented to the emperor :8. and a 1609 map in two hemispheres.<ref name="Day"/>
Most of these maps now are lost. Later copies of the 1602 edition of the ''Kunyu Wanguo Quantu'' may be found in China, Korea, London, and Vienna;<ref>A reproduction of the Vienna map can be found in Österreichisch Nationalbibliothek (1995).''Kartographische Zimelien. Die 50 schönsten Karten und Globen der Österreichischen Nationalbibliothek''. Wien: Holzhausen.</ref> one copy of the map recently was discovered in the store-rooms of the [[Shenyang#Museums|Shenyang Museum]] in China. A world search is currently in progress by Kendall Whaling Museum of Massachusetts.<ref name="Battistini"/> Hong Weilian,<ref name="Kao"/> earlier established a list of twelve total Ricci maps, which differs considerably from Day’s findings.<ref name="Ptak">{{cite journal|last=Ptak|first=Roderich|year=2005 |title=The Sino-European Map ("Shanhai yudi quantu") in the Encyclopedia Sancai tuhui |publisher=[http://www.humanismolatino.online.pt Humanismo Latino]|pages=1–17|url=http://www.humanismolatino.online.pt/v1/pdf/C003-022.pdf}}</ref>
In 1607 or 1609 the ''[[Shanhai Yudi Quantu]]'', is a Chinese map which was published in the geographical treatise [[Sancai Tuhui]]. The Shanhai Yudi Quantu was influenced highly by the work of [[Matteo Ricci]].<ref>Ptak, p.1</ref> Matteo Ricci had several of his own maps entitled ''Shanhai Yudi Quantu''.<ref>Ptak, p.3</ref> The locations in the map have been identified and translated by Roderich Ptak in his work, ''The Sino-European Map (“Shanhai yudi quantu”), in the Encyclopedia Sancai tuhui'':<ref name="Ptak"/>
About 1620 [[Giulio Aleni]] made the world map ''[[Wanguo Quantu]]'' (萬國全圖, lit. "Complete map of all the countries"), putting China at the center of the world map, following Ricci's format and contents, but in a much smaller size (49 cm x 24 cm). This map was included in some editions of Aleni's geographical work, ''[[Zhifang waiji]]''. (Descriptions of Foreign Land) His 1623 preface states that another Jesuit, [[Diego de Pantoja]] (1571–1618), on the command of the emperor, had translated a different European map, also following Ricci's model, but there is no other knowledge of that work.<ref name="Chen"/>
In 1633, the Jesuit, [[Francesco Sambiasi]] (1582–1649), composed and annotated another world map, entitled ''Kunyu Quantu'' (Universal Map of the World), in [[Nanjing]].
In 1674, [[Ferdinand Verbiest]] developed the ''[[Kunyu Quantu]]'', a similar map, but with various improvements.<ref name="Verbiest">{{cite web|url=http://u21museums.unimelb.edu.au/museumcollections/glasgow/hunterian/map.html|title=KUNYU QUANTU (A Map of the Whole World)|last=Verbiest|first=Ferdinand |year=1674|work=Museum's Gateway|publisher=[[University of Melbourne]], [[Universitas 21]]|accessdate=13 January 2010|location=Melbourne}}</ref> It consists of eight panels, each 179 cm x 54 cm, together displaying two hemispheres in [[Mercator projection]]. The two outer scrolls individually depict cartouches that contain several kinds of information on geography and meteorology. The making of Verbiest's ''Kunyu Quantu'' was intended to meet the interest of the [[Kangxi Emperor]], as Verbiest's introductory dedication implies. There currently are at least fourteen or fifteen copies and editions of this map known in Europe, Japan, Taiwan, America, and Australia.<ref name="Chen"/>
==Religious significance== Chen, Hui-hung discussed the religious meaning of the world maps that were produced by [[Society of Jesus|Jesuit]] [[Christian missionaries|missionaries]] in China from the late sixteenth to the seventeenth centuries. These world maps serve as a visual proof to emphasize the greatness of the world and the minuscule nature of humans. Through these maps people "can see" the truth of God because of the visual ability granted via God's omnipotence. Jesuit cartography was not only a visual image of geographical configuration: it paved the way for the comprehension of what they expressed as the Creator's significance.
It was an embodiment of the Renaissance tradition of cartography as the graphical representation of the universe. This includes the idea of understanding nature through mathematical science as well as understanding Heaven by visualization and sensibility. In this Renaissance tradition, geography was associated with [[cosmology]] that was based upon Christian theology. These maps expressed Aristotle's sensibility toward comprehension of the universe, which formed the core of Catholic epistemology and natural philosophy. The religious implications of Jesuit cartography in China are part of how the Jesuits used their cartographic superiority strategically in their evangelization.<ref name="Chen">{{cite journal|last=Chen|first=Hui-hung|date= July 2007 |title=The Human Body as a Universe: Understanding Heaven by Visualization and Sensibility in Jesuit Cartography in China |journal=The Catholic Historical Review |publisher=The Catholic University of America Press |volume=93|issue=3|pages= 517–552|issn=0008-8080 |url=http://muse.jhu.edu/login?url=http://www.britannica.com/bps/additionalcontent/18/27874241/THE-HUMAN-BODY-AS-A-UNIVERSE-UNDERSTANDING-HEAVEN-BY-VISUALIZATION-AND-SENSIBILITY-IN-JESUIT-CARTOGRAPHY-IN-CHINA |doi=10.1353/cat.2007.0236}}</ref>
Ricci was a Jesuit priest whose mission was to convert the Chinese to Roman Catholicism. He thought that might be helped by demonstrating the superior understanding of the world that he believed grew out of Christian faith. The map’s text shows it as part of a diplomatic attempt by Ricci to affirm the greatness of his own religion and culture. Ricci declares that it offers testimony “to the supreme goodness, greatness and unity of Him who controls heaven and earth.”<ref name="Rothstein">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/20/arts/design/20map.html?pagewanted=1|title=Map That Shrank the World|last=Rothstein|first=Edward |date=2010-01-19|work=New York Times, Arts, EXHIBITION REVIEW |publisher=New York Times Company|accessdate=20 January 2010|location=New York}}</ref>
== Gallery == <gallery> File:Ricci map 1602.jpg|unknown edition or poor copy of 1602 Ricci map File:Wanguo Quantu.jpg|1620s ''Wanguo Quantu'' map, by [[Giulio Aleni]], whose Chinese name (艾儒略) appears in the signature in the last column on the left, above the Jesuit [[Christogram|IHS]] symbol.<ref name="Vatican exhibit">[http://www.ibiblio.org/expo/vatican.exhibit/exhibit/i-rome_to_china/Rome_to_china.html Vatican exhibit]</ref> File:Impossible Black Tulip-World map, Gulf of Mexico, Florida.jpg|1602 Ricci map - detail of Gulf of Mexico, Florida, Cuba, Yucatan, Mexico File: Impossible_Black_Tulip-_World_map,_detail_from_the_China_section.jpg|1602 Ricci map - detail from a China panel File: Ricci1602North&CentralAmerica.jpg|1602 Ricci map - detail of North and Central America File: Matteo Ricci Far East 1602 Larger.jpg|Detail of China and Far East, from the 1604 copy </gallery>

Shapero] * [http://www.ias.umn.edu/media/BatofMinerva/AnnWaltner-Ricci.php Interview with Ann Waltner about map]

page.title: List of European countries by population

revision.comment: Please doublecheck, I strongly suppose, this is the proper order by number of native speakers
revision.text:
{{Disputed|date=January 2016}} [[File:European countries by population, 2018.png|thumb|European countries by population|300px]] '''List of European countries by population''' present the list of 50 countries and 8 territories and dependencies located in [[Europe]]. Transcontinental countries are included if they are members of the [[Council of Europe]]. The most populated country wholly within [[Europe]] is [[Germany]]. The largest city by total land area are [[Paris]] and [[London]], [[Moscow]], [[Berlin]] and [[Istanbul]]. The most spoken languages are [[Russian language|Russian]], [[German language|German]], [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] and [[Polish language|Polish]]. ==Table== {{small|{{Pie chart | thumb = right | caption= European population by country (top 10). | other = yes | label1 = Russia | value1 = 17.16 | color1=#36A | label3 = Turkey | value3 = 9.62 | color2=#53A | label2 = Germany | value2 = 9.90 | color3=#1A9 | label4 = France | value4 = 7.88 | color4=#CC5 | label5 = United Kingdom | value5 = 7.78 | color5=#928 | label6 = Italy | value6 = 7.21 | color6=#E33 | label7 = Spain | value7 = 5.54 | color7=#E72 | label8 = Ukraine | value8 = 5.10 | color8=#FE3 | label9 = Poland | value9 = 4.62 | color9=#D1AB00 | label10 = Romania | value10 = 2.36 | color10=#E55 }}}} {{color box|#b3ffb3}} [[Transcontinental countries]] largely located in [[Asia]].

'''Noul Neamț Monastery''' ({{lang-ro|Mănăstirea Noul Neamț}}; {{lang-ru|Свято-Вознесенский Ново-Нямецкий монастырь}}) is an all-male [[Moldovan Orthodox Church|Moldovan Orthodox]] [[monastery]] located in [[Chiţcani]], near [[Bender, Moldova|Bender]] and [[Tiraspol]]. Geographically located in the historical region of [[Basarabia]], it is today controlled by the breakaway [[Transnistria]]n authorities. It is also known as '''Chițcani Monastery'''.
==Overview== The name (which means "New Neamț" in English) signifies that the monastery is a successor of the [[Neamț Monastery]] in medieval [[Moldavia]].
The monastery was founded in 1861, when several monks from the Neamț monastery left and founded Noul-Neamț in Chițcani. The founding of the new monastery was a protest against the measures taken in [[United Principalities|United Principalities of Romania]] to [[Secularization of monastery estates in Romania|confiscate monastery estates]] and forbid the usage of Slavonic language in worship.<ref>[http://www.referat.ro/referate/Rena__351_terea_M_tirii_Noul_Neamt_06bab.htm Renașterea mînăstirii Noul Neamț]</ref> At the time, Chițcani, like all of Bessarabia, was part of the [[Russian Empire]] since 1812.
On 16 May 1962 Soviet authorities closed the monastery; the buildings became a hospital.
The monastery church was reopened in 1989, followed in 1991 by the Romanian-language school for Orthodox priests.<ref>[http://www.crestinortodox.ro/Manastirea_Noul_Neamt___lavra_Basarabiei-24-289.html Noul Neamț monastery, article in "Lumea Credinței"] {{ro icon}}</ref> Since 1992, the town is controlled by the internationally not recognised state of [[Transnistria]].
== Gallery == <gallery> Image:Kitskany-8.jpg Image:Sc0016f2c2.png|Carving in a tree on the territory of the monastery Image:Kitskany-9.jpg Image:Stamp of Moldova 438.gif|1997 stamp </gallery>

revision.text:
'''Polish Radio Wilno''' ({{lang-pl|Polskie Radio Wilno}}) was a station of the [[Polish Radio]], located in the city of [[Wilno]] (now [[Vilnius]], [[Lithuania]]), which in the interbellum period belonged to the [[Second Polish Republic]].
Irregular daily broadcasts began on November 28, 1927, and on December 4, 1927, the station began its normal operation.<ref>{{cite book | last =Miszczak | first=Stanisław | title =Historia radiofonii i telewizji w Polsce | publisher = Wydawnictwo Komunikacji i Łączności | year = 1972 | location = Warsaw }}</ref> Official opening ceremony took place on January 15, 1928.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://historiaradia.neostrada.pl/Historia.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-09-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081020002014/http://historiaradia.neostrada.pl/Historia.html |archivedate=2008-10-20 |df= }}</ref> Original frequency was 690 kHz, but it was changed several times, and since mid-1930s, until the outbreak of [[World War II]], the frequency was 536 kHz.
In the years 1927–1931, the station was located in [[Wilno]]’s district of [[Žvėrynas|Zwierzyniec]] ({{coord|54.6887344|25.2572966|dim:100|format=dms}}). In 1931 a new transmitting station was opened in the district of Lipówka ({{coord|54.6535259|25.3019179|dim:100|format=dms}}). It had one 16 kW transmitter (increased to 50 kW in 1936) and an antenna mounted between two 70 meter towers. Yet another station was under construction in the district of Krzyżówka ({{coord|54.7019724|25.2269448|dim:100|format=dms}}), but the outbreak of [[World War II]] prevented its completion.
Among most popular broadcasts there was daily transmission of Roman Catholic mass services from the famous [[chapel]] of [[Gate of Dawn|Ostra Brama]].
The Lipówka station was bombed by German [[Luftwaffe]] on September 16, 1939, during Germany's [[Polish September Campaign]].<ref>Die Berichte des Oberkommandos der Wehrmacht 1939-1945. Köln : Parkland Verlag, 2004. {{ISBN|3-89340-063-X}}.</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== See also == *[[Radio stations in interwar Poland]] *[[1927 in radio]] *[[Elektrit]]
