{{redirect|Marcopolo|the explorer|Marco Polo|other uses|Marco Polo (disambiguation)}} {{Other uses|Thor (disambiguation)}} '''Thor''' (previously known as '''Marcopolo''') is a family of [[Communications satellite|satellites]] designed, launched and tested by [[Hughes Space and Communications]] (now part of [[Boeing Satellite Systems]]) for [[British Satellite Broadcasting]] (BSB), and were used for [[United Kingdom|Britain]]'s [[Direct Broadcast Service]]. Thor is owned by [[Telenor]].<ref>[http://www.boeing.com/defense-space/space/bss/factsheets/376/bsb/bsb.html BSB History by Boeing] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090120074306/http://www.boeing.com/defense-space/space/bss/factsheets/376/bsb/bsb.html |date=2009-01-20 }}</ref> Marcopolo 1 launched on 27 August 1989 on the 187th launch of a [[Delta (rocket)|Delta]] rocket, and Marcopolo 2 launched on 17 August 1990, on a Delta II rocket.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boeing.com/defense-space/space/bls/missions/index.html|title=Boeing Launch Services Mission Record|publisher=Boeing}}</ref> Marcopolo I had the Hughes designation HS376.<ref>[http://www.nasm.si.edu/research/arch/findaids/pdf/Desind_Finding_Aid.pdf] NASM's Herbert Stephen Desind Collection,p. 36</ref>
Although the satellites performed as designed, BSB<ref>[http://www.tbs-satellite.com/tse/online/sat_bsb_1.html BSB1]</ref> merged with [[Sky Television plc|Sky Television]] to form [[British Sky Broadcasting]] and the BSB satellites were sold off and renamed. This also resulted in the obsoletion of the [[Squarial]] satellite-reception antenna, which was designed to operate with Thor 1 only.
==Marcopolo 1 (Sirius 1/Sirius W)== [[Sirius 1 (satellite)|Sirius W]], previously known as Sirius 1, was launched on 27 August 1989. It was [[Hughes Space and Communications]]'s first satellite. Marcopolo 1 was sold in December 1993 to [[Nordic Satellite AB]] of Sweden and operated until 2000 as Sirius 1 at 5°E. It was then moved to 13°W, and renamed Sirius W. It had 5 K<sub>u</sub> band transponders.
==Marcopolo 2 (Thor 1)== Marcopolo 2 was launched on 18 August 1990. It had 5 K<sub>u</sub> band transponders. It was sold in July 1992 to [[Telenor]] of [[Norway]] and renamed Thor 1. It was located at 0.8°W. It was switched off in January 2002, and in November of that year it was moved to 7.4°W and reactivated with digital test signals broadcasting toward [[Scandinavia]]. Marcopolo 2 was sent up to the [[junk orbit]] in early January 2003.
==Thor 2== Thor 2 was launched on 21 May 1997, and retired in 2008 although it remained in an inclined geostationary orbit until January 2013 when it de-orbited to the graveyard orbit.<ref>{{cite web|last=Clover|first=Julian|title=Thor II de-orbited after 15 years|url=http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2013/01/14/thor-ii-de-orbited-after-15-years/|publisher=Broadband TV News|accessdate=14 January 2013}}</ref> It weighs 1467 kg, and has 15 K<sub>u</sub> band transponders, with 3 spares, powered by 40-watt traveling-wave tube amplifiers (TWTAs).
==Thor 3== Thor 3 (the "3" is officially "III") was a [[satellite]] used by [[Canal Digital]] in the Nordic areas for [[Direct To Home|DTH]] services. It launched on 9 June 1998 with an expected lifetime at 12 years, and was located at 0.8°W. It had 14 active K<sub>u</sub> band transponders powered by 47-watt traveling-wave tube amplifiers (TWTAs). The satellite was targeted on [[Scandinavia]], [[East Europe|Eastern Europe]], and parts of [[Central Europe]].<ref>http://telenorsbc.com/templates/Page.aspx?id=377</ref> Thor 3 is still in operation and is flying in inclined geostationary orbit but has been pointed towards the middle east. Thor 3 was replaced by Thor 6 in June 2010.
==Intelsat 10-02 (Thor 4)== [[Intelsat|Intelsat 10-02]] was launched on 16 June 2004, located at 1°W, and was beamed toward [[Central Europe]] and the [[Middle East]].
==Thor 5== Thor 5 was launched on 11 February 2008. It was first planned that the satellite would be called Thor 2R', but Telenor named it Thor 5. It has 24 active K<sub>u</sub> band transponders.
==Thor 6== Thor 6 was launched<ref>[http://www.telenorsbc.com/templates/Page.aspx?id=777 Telenor Satellite Broadcasting]</ref> from the Guiana Spaceport on 29 October 2009. Telenor Satellite Broadcasting announced on 15 December that Thor 6 had completed all necessary in-orbit and ground-related testing and would commence commercial service in late December.
Thor 6 has 36 K<sub>u</sub> band transponders. It provides direct-to-home television broadcasting services from the orbital location 0.8°W. It replaced Thor 3.<ref>[http://www.telenorsbc.com/templates/Page.aspx?id=796 Telenor Satellite Broadcasting]</ref>
==Thor 7== Thor 7 has been built by [[SSL (company)|SSL]]. It was successfully launched by [[Arianespace]] from [[Kourou]] spaceport on 26 April 2015. It will mainly serve maritime customers and have a total capacity of 9 Gbit/sec. It was launched in tandem with the Italian/French [[Sicral]] 2 defense satellite.
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://satellitecoverage.net/footprints/?sat=191 Thor 3 coverage map] * [http://satellitecoverage.net/footprints/?sat=165 Thor 4 (Intelsat 10-02) coverage map] * [http://satellitecoverage.net/footprints/?sat=178 Thor 5 coverage map] * [http://satellitecoverage.net/footprints/?sat=177 Thor 6 coverage map] * [http://satellitecoverage.net/footprints/?sat=306 Thor 7 coverage map]

{{short description|North Korean Special Operation Forces unit}} {{Infobox military unit | unit_name = Unit 124 | image = | caption = | dates = | country = {{flagcountry|Democratic People's Republic of Korea}} | allegiance = | branch = [[North Korean Special Operation Force]] | type = [[Black operation|Black op]] [[special forces]] | role = Assassinate [[Park Chung-hee]] | size = 31 | command_structure= | current_commander= | garrison = | nickname = | patron = | motto = | colorsanalyn = | march = | mascot = | battles = | anniversaries = }} '''Unit 124''' was a [[North Korean Special Operation Force]]s unit, in the [[Korean People's Army]] (KPA).<ref>{{Cite book|last=Bolger|first=Daniel|title=Scenes from an Unfinished War: Low intensity conflict in Korea 1966-1969|publisher=Diane Publishing Co|isbn=978-0-7881-1208-9|year=1991|page=Figure 3}}</ref> Thirty-one men from the unit were handpicked to raid the [[Blue House]] and assassinate South Korean president [[Park Chung-hee]] in 1968.<ref name="JoongAng Daily">{{cite web|url=http://joongangdaily.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=2912061|title=A would-be assassin builds a new life|publisher=JoongAng Daily|date=4 November 2009}}</ref>
The [[Blue House raid]] failed, with 29 members of the unit being killed and one, [[Kim Shin-jo]], captured. Just one member of the unit, [[Pak Jae-gyong]], made it back to North Korea. He went on to become a general in the KPA, and a Vice Minister in the [[Ministry of People's Armed Forces]].<ref name="JoongAng Daily"/>
Although the unit was believed to have been disbanded after the raid,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2010/02/120_59604.html|title=January 1968: Assassins storm Seoul; US spyship seized|publisher=The Korea Times|date=24 January 2010}}</ref> it has been succeeded by the KPA's [[Special Battalions]], part of the [[Reconnaissance Agency]], formed to conduct intelligence gathering, espionage, terrorism and [[North Korean abductions of South Koreans|abduction operations in South Korea]].
== See also == {{Portal|Military history|Korea}} * [[209th Detachment, 2325th Group]] - its South Korean counterpart
== References == {{Reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}}

'''William de Falaise''' (11th century), also called '''William of Falaise''', was a Norman from [[Falaise, Calvados|Falaise]], [[Duchy of Normandy]], today in the [[Calvados (department)|Calvados]] [[Departments of France|department]] in the [[Lower Normandy]] [[Regions of France|region]] of north-western France. He became [[English feudal barony|feudal baron]] of [[Stogursey]] in Somerset and also held manors in Devon.
==Biography== William married Geva de Burci (her second husband), who was the daughter and sole heiress of [[Serlo de Burcy]], feudal baron of Blagdon, Somerset, which barony is sometimes stated to be of Dartington, Devon, as the ''[[caput]]'' cannot be clearly assigned exclusively to either place.<ref>Sanders, Ivor J., ''English Baronies'', Oxford, 1960, p. 15</ref> Geva's first husband was "Martin" (died before 1086) for whom she produced a son and heir, Robert FitzMartin (died 1159), who with his descendants were feudal barons of Blagdon. William's daughter and sole heiress to the feudal barony of Stogursey was Emma of Falaise, who married [[William de Courcy (died circa 1114)|William de Courcy]] (died about 1114), to whose descendants the barony of Stogursey passed. The Devon lands of William of Falaise however passed to the FitzMartin family, feudal barons of Blagdon, who were sometimes seated at his former manor of Dartington.
==Landholdings== The [[Liber Exoniensis|Exeter Domesday Book]] lists him as holding the following 17 Devon manors as a [[tenant-in-chief]] of the king:<ref>Thorn, Caroline & Frank, Domesday Book, Vol.9, Devon, vol.2 (notes), Chichester, 1985, Chapter 20</ref> *Combe Martin, in Braunton Hundred *Furse, possibly Furze in [[West Buckland]] in Braunton Hundred *[[Parracombe]], in [[Shirwell]] Hundred *Churchill, in East Down parish, Braunton Hundred *"Beare", possibly a lost Beare in Worlington, Witheridge Hundred *Washford Pyne in Witheridge Hundred *Worlington, in Witheridge Hundred *Bradford, in Witheridge Hundred *Densham, in Woolfardisworthy parish *Cockington, in Haytor Hundred *Holne, now a parish, in Stanborough Hundred *Stoke, in Holne parish, in Stanborough Hundred *Dean Prior, a parish in Stanborough Hundred *Rattery, a parish in Stanborough Hundred *Dartington, a parish in Stanborough Hundred *Harbourneford, in South Brent parish in Stanborough Hundred *Englebourne, now in Harberton parish, Coleridge Hundred.
He is listed as ''Wilts de Faleise'', holding 3 Somerset manors as tenant-in-chief:<ref>[http://opendomesday.org/name/590450/william-of-falaise/ Open Domesday Online: William of Falaise]</ref> *[[Stogursey]], in Cannington Hundred *Wootton [Courtenay], in Carhampton Hundred *Woodspring, in Winterstoke Hundred
==Sources== *Thorn, Caroline & Frank, ''Domesday Book, Vol. 9, Devon'', vol. 1, Chichester, 1985, Chapter 20, holdings of William de Falaise. *Sanders, Ivor J., 'Barony of Blagdon' in ''English Baronies'' (Oxford, 1960), p. 15,
==References== <references/>
